The overall emergency response program for the Houston Gas Plant is coordinated with the Washington County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).  This coordination includes periodic meetings of the committee, which includes local emergency response officials, local government officials, and industry representatives.  The Houston Gas Plant has around-the-clock communications capability with appropriate LEPC officials and emergency response organizations (e.g., fire department).  This provides a means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident.  In addition to periodic LEPC meetings, the Houston Gas Plant conducts periodic emergency drills that involve the LEPC and emergency response organizations, and the facility provides annual refresher training to local emergency responders regarding the hazards of regulated substances in the facility.

The Management of Change provisions ensure that the Houston facility considers the potential safety and health impacts of each change made to chemicals, technology, equipment or procedures.

The PHA provisions serve as a tool to ensure continual evaluation of potential hazards, thereby leading to continual improvements in safety standards.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATION

The Houston Gas Plant is a Non-Responding Facility as per 48 CFR 68.90(b).  The facility maintains a written emergency action plan, which is in pace to help protect employees and public safety as well as the environment.  The plan identifies steps to be taken in case of an accidental release including: evacuation plans, accounting for personnel after an evacuation, and notification of company staff, local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs.  However, facility personnel are not trained to be first responders to large fires and should a release occur from one of the vessels the Houston Plant would rely on the local fire department to respond.

at must be managed to ensure continued safe operation.  The following is a description of existing safety features applicable to prevention of accidental releases of regulated substances in the facility.  

Universal Prevention Activities

The accident prevention program summarized previously is applied to all RMP-covered processes at the Houston Gas Plant.  Collectively, these prevention program activities prevent or mitigate potential accident scenarios that could be caused by equipment failures and human errors.

Specialized Safety Features

The Houston Gas Plant has safety features on many units to help (1) contain/control a release, (2) quickly detect a release, and (3) reduce the consequences of (mitigate) a release.  The following types of safety features are used in the covered process:

Release Detection

1.  Hand-held hydrocarbon detectors operated by facility personnel.  
2.  Personnel are on site 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.
  
Release Containment/Control

1.  Process relief valves that discharge to a flare to capture and incinerate episodic releases.
2.  Valves to permit isolation of the process (manual and automated).
3.  Automated shutdown systems for specific process parameters (e.g., high temperature)
4.  Curbing or dyking to contain liquid releases.
5.  Redundant equipment and instrumentation (e.g., uninterruptible power supply for process control system).

Release Mitigation

1.  Deluge system for specific equipment.
2.  Trained emergency response personnel.
3.  Personal protective equipment (e.g., chemical protective clothing).

Hot Work Permit

MPLX, L.P. and MarkWest Liberty M&R, L.L.C., uses a hot work permit for hot work operations including grinding, welding, and spark producing activities conducted on or near a covered process.  The hot work permit documents the fire prevention and protection requirements prior to beginning hot work operations. The permit indicates the days on which hot work may be performed and the object upon which hot work is to be performed. Hot work permits are kept in a place that is easily accessible for the workers and on file at the office until the completion of hot work operations.

Contractors

The Houston Gas Plant uses contractors to supplement its workforce during periods of increased maintenance or construction activities.  Because some contractors work on or near process equipment, the plant has procedures in place to ensure that contractors: perform their work in a safe manner; have the appropriate knowledge and skills; are aware of the hazards in their workplace; understand what they should do in event of an emergency; understand and follow site safety rules; and inform facility personnel of any hazards that they find during their work.  This is accomplished by providing contractors with: a process overview; information about potential fire, explosion, or toxic release hazards; emergency response plan requirements; and safe work practices prior to their beginning work.  In addition, the Houston Gas Plant will only select contractors who submit certification that employees are trained in specifics and safe work practices associated with their job, and that provide safety performance documentation from the previous three years.  Finally, facility personnel periodically monitor contractor performance to ensure that contractors are fulfilling their safety obligations.

Incident Investigation

MPLX, L.P. and MarkWest Liberty M&R, L.L.C., promptly investigates all incidents that resulted in, or reasonably could have resulted in, a fire/explosion, release, major property damage, environmental loss, or personal injury.  The goal of each investigation is to determine the facts, determine what error states led to the incident and to develop corrective actions to prevent a recurrence of the incident or a similar incident.  The investigation team consists of the immediate supervisor, one person knowledgeable in the process, and other members with appropriate experience to investigate and analyze the incident.  The team documents its findings, develops recommendations to prevent a recurrence, and forwards these results to facility management for resolution.  Corrective actions that are identified will be promptly addressed, resolved and tracked until they are complete.  The final resolution of each finding or recommendation is documented, and the investigation results are reviewed with all employees (including contractors) whose job tasks are relevant to the investigation.  Incident investigation reports are retained for at least 5 years so that the reports can be reviewed during PHAs and PHA revalidations.

Examples of employee participation range from updating and compiling technical documents and chemical information to participating as a member of a process hazard analysis (PHA) team.  Employees will be provided with all information created as part of the facility accident prevention program.  Specific ways that employees can be involved in the accident preventi

Pre-startup Safety Reviews (PSSRs)

MPLX, L.P. and MarkWest Liberty M&R, L.L.C., conducts a PSSR for any new facility or facility modification that requires a change in the process safety information.  The PSSR confirm that construction was completed in accordance with design specifications, that safety, operating, maintenance, and emergency procedures are in place and are adequate.  The PSSR will be reviewed and appropriately updated during the management of change process.  The PSSR will ensure that: modifications were installed as described; no other changes were made outside the original scope of work; operating procedures have been modified and communicated to operating and maintenance personnel; all necessary tests have been completed prior to start-up; all site safety, fire protection, and environmental issues have been addressed; the startup plan has been reviewed; pertinent drawing have been red-lined or updated to as-built requirements; vendor files have been updated; and training of affected personnel has been performed and documented.

Compliance Audits

To help ensure that the accident prevention program is functioning properly, MPLX, L.P. and MarkWest Liberty M&R, L.L.C., periodically conducts an audit to determine whether the procedures and practices required by the accident prevention program are being implemented.  Compliance audits are conducted at least every 3 years.  Both hourly and staff personnel participate as audit team members.  Team membership will include at least one person knowledgeable of the system being audited.  One member of the team must be qualified to lead the audit and be familiar with the auditing protocol being administered. Maintenance personnel receive training on an overview of the process, safety and health hazards, applicable maintenance procedures, emergency response plans, and applicable safe work practices to help ensure that they can perform their jobs in a safe manner.  Job plans/written procedures help ensure that work is performed in a consistent manner and provide a basis for training.  Inspections and tests are performed to help ensure that equipment functions as intended and to verify that equipment is within acceptable limits (e.g., adequate wall thickness for pressure vessels).  If a deficiency is identified, employees will correct the deficiency before placing the equipment back into service (if possible), or a management of change team will review the use of the equipment and determine what actions are necessary to ensure the safe operation of the equipment.

Another integral part of the mechanical integrity is quality assurance.  The Houston Gas Plant incorporates quality assurance measures into equipment purchases and repairs.  This helps ensure that new equipment is suitable for its intended use and that proper materials and spare parts are used when repairs are made.

Management of Change

MPLX, L.P. and MarkWest Liberty M&R, L.L.C., has a comprehensive system to manage changes to all covered processes.  This system requires that changes to items such as process equipment, chemicals, technology (including process operating conditions), procedures, and other facility changes be properly reviewed and authorized before being implemented.  Changes are reviewed to ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards and to verify that existing controls have not been compromised by the change.  Affected chemical hazard information, process operating limits, and equipment information, as well as procedures, are up

ed and retained.  

Operating Procedures

MPLX, L.P. and MarkWest Liberty M&R, L.L.C., maintains written procedures that address various modes of operations, such as:  initial startup; normal operations; temporary operations; emergency shutdown; normal shutdown; emergency operations; and startup following a turnaround.  These procedures can be used as a reference by experienced operators and provide a basis for consistent training of new operators.  These procedures are periodically reviewed and annually certified as current and accurate.  The procedures are kept current and accurate by revising them as necessary to reflect changes made through the management of change process.  The operating procedures are centrally located and accessible to all employees.

Training

To complement the written procedures for process operations, the Houston Gas Plant has implemented a comprehensive training program for all employees involved in operating a process.  New employees receive basic training in facility operations unless they provide written certification that they have the required knowledge, skills and abilities to safely carry out their specific duties and responsibilities. All MPLX employees at the Houston plant will be trained in PSM/RMP requirement upon hire as part of their qualification to work.  All operations employees will undergo refresher training at least every three years.  A training attendance record will be kept for all training activities and a verification of understanding will be conducted by a performance evaluation or through testing.

The analyses are conducted using a team of people who have operating and maintenance experience as well as engineering expertise.  This team identifies and evaluates hazards of the process as well as accident prevention and mitigation measures, and the team makes suggestions for additional prevention and/or mitigation measures when the team believes such measures are necessary.

Each PHA will address the following:
a) hazards of the process,

e) facility siting issues,

The PHA team findings are compiled in a written report and are forwarded to local and corporate management for resolution.  Implementation of mitigation options in response to PHA findings is based on a relative risk ranking assigned by the PHA team.  This ranking helps ensure that potential accident scenarios assigned that highest risk receive immediate attention.  All approved mitigation options in response to PHA team findings are tracked until they are completed.  The final resolution of each finding is documented and retained.

This information, in combination with written procedures and trained personnel, provides a basis for establishing inspection and maintenance activities, as well as for evaluating proposed process and facility changes to ensure that safety features in the process are not compromised.

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY - HOUSTON GAS PLANT

MPLX, L.P. and MarkWest Liberty M&R, L.L.C. owner and operator of the Houston Gas Plant, has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as training personnel and considering safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of our processes.  Our policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances.  However, if a release does occur, facility trained personnel will respond to control and contain the release. Other safety measures such as fire suppression, ambulatory, or evacuation of the community is coordinated and handled through local emergency response personnel in the community.

DESCRIPTION OF THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

The Houston Gas Plant processes raw gas from a field gathering system.  Produced natural gas is brought into the plant where it is first dehydrated to remove water.  The gas is then sent through refrigeration dew point control units where the condensable liquids will be extracted from the methane gas stream.  The gas is then sent through the turbo expander for additional pressure drop and liquids removal.  After passing through the turbo expander both the gas and liquids are sent to the demethanizer tower through different inlet trays.  The gas rises through the top and is ready to be sent into the sales pipeline.  The liquids are separated and sent through the bottom and to the surge tank and depropanzier.  A fractionator process then takes the B-G liquids and separates the iso- and normal- butane leaving natural gasoline.  A deethanizer removes ethane from the liquid stream and is sold via pipeline as a purity product.
